description: From Middle English snot, snotte, from Old English ġesnot, *snott, from Proto-Germanic *snuttuz (“nasal mucus”), from the same base as snout. Related also to snite.

Cognate with North Frisian snot (“snot”), Saterland Frisian Snotte (“snot”), West Frisian snotte (“snot”), Dutch snot (“snot”), German Low German Snött (“snot”), dialectal German Schnutz (“snot”), Danish snot (“snot”), Norwegian snott (“snot”).

entries.meaning: (informal, uncountable) Mucus, especially mucus from the nose.
(Northern England, dialectal) The flamed out wick of a candle.
(US ?, figurative, informal) A blemish or encumbrance that one exercises out of something.

verbs.description: snot (third-person singular simple present snots, present participle snotting, simple past and past participle snotted)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To blow, wipe, or clear (the nose).
(intransitive) To sniff or snivel; to produce snot, to have a runny nose.
examples: I was snotting all into my mouth and having to eat it, silently shuddering.
